channel.title: Mensa welcomes its youngest member
channel.description:
She said her first word at five months, took her first steps at eight and a half and now she is two Elise Roberts can name 35 capital cities. But that is not all. With an intelligence far beyond her years the toddler from north London in England has become the youngest member of the high IQ society Mensa. Edward Nosegbe-Roberts, Elise’s father, spotted his daughter’s gifts early on: “Well she was just very quick and observant. You know, she’d see things and you’d tell her things once or twice and she would remember them.” Elise’s IQ is 156 – the average is 100. Her parents soon felt a little out their depth and contacted Mensa for extra support. “We don’t really know what to do. You know we do need guidance, we do sort of need help as it were, and they’ve been really helpful in giving us advice on what we should do,” says Elise’s dad.
sauce: http://www.euronews.net/2009/05/02/mensa-welcomes-its-youngest-member/ Smart little bitch. But WAIT! She's black, must be fake!

item.title: Mensa welcomes its youngest member
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:9, topic:277037”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=365708.msg2776122#msg2776122 date=1241546187]
Just because she is ‘intelligent’ now won’t mean you’ll hear much from her in the future. There are many people who were smart when they were young that you never hear from again.
[/quote]

That’s because they do brilliant things. The public isn’t interested in brilliant things, they’re interested in stuff like celebrities breaking up and the like; so the newspapers etc. don’t report it. But that doesn’t mean they (The intelligent ones) aren’t doing anything.[/quote]

Many intelligent people get bored, because there are no challenges. So they often end up in the gutter.

Read full topic

item.title: Mensa welcomes its youngest member
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Cowie`, post:5, topic:277037”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=365708.msg2774206#msg2774206 date=1241421499]
Wow. :o That’s quite incredible.
[/quote]

Nothing like that happens in Australia.[/quote]
Well, actually, there are Mensa groups in all of the capital cities here. Most Australians don’t have an inferiority complex though, so you won’t find us on the news seeking glory and what not.

She said her first word at five months, took her first steps at eight and a half and now she is two Elise Roberts can name 35 capital cities.

But that is not all. With an intelligence far beyond her years the toddler from north London in England has become the youngest member of the high IQ society Mensa.

Edward Nosegbe-Roberts, Elise’s father, spotted his daughter’s gifts early on: “Well she was just very quick and observant. You know, she’d see things and you’d tell her things once or twice and she would remember them.”

Elise’s IQ is 156 – the average is 100. Her parents soon felt a little out their depth and contacted Mensa for extra support.

“We don’t really know what to do. You know we do need guidance, we do sort of need help as it were, and they’ve been really helpful in giving us advice on what we should do,” says Elise’s dad.
